We can use the concept of magnetic induction and the Lorentz force to solve this problem.
The particle enters the magnetic field B1 perpendicularly to MN at point O, with velocity vector directed upward.
The magnetic induction vector is directed perpendicular to the magnetic field lines and points in the direction of the velocity vector.
The magnetic force F on the particle is given by the equation F = qvB, where q is the charge of the particle, v is the velocity of the particle, and B is the magnetic induction intensity.
The magnetic force vector is directed perpendicular to the magnetic induction vector and the velocity vector.
The time t it takes for the particle to pass through point O again is given by the equation t = L/v, where L is the length of the path the particle takes in the magnetic field.

The length of the path L is the distance the particle travels in the magnetic field. Since the particle enters the magnetic field perpendicularly and exits it perpendicularly, the path is a straight line.
The length of the path L can be calculated using the formula L = d/2, where d is the distance between the two magnetic field lines.
Substituting the values into the equation for time: t = L/v = (d/2)/v = d/(2v).
The relationship between the magnitudes of the magnetic induction intensities B1 and B2 is given as B1 = 2B2.
Substituting the values into the equation for time: t = d/(2v) = d/(2 * 2B2) = d/(4B2).
